content.title: Melloo, musical street food

introduction.small: Paying a pizza or a burger in records? At Melloo, it is possible. This small street food restaurant is popular among music collectors and DJ sets.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Melloo, musical street food

paragraphs.text:
The relaxed atmosphere can be felt even before you pass the threshold: through the picture window of this small, trendy restaurant in the Novoli neighbourhood, you will notice a bunch of hipsters and music lovers trade vinyl records against a burger, a pizza or some craft beer. Melloo is all for trading, and the concept is popular among DJ set aficionados and food lovers. The pizza dough is homemade, using only handmade organic flour, and slowly rises for 56 hours before it is baked.

More importantly, pizzas, burgers and other tapas take a different flavour when enjoyed while listening to audiophile records. Melloo's collection built through trades grows day by day and remains accessible to all. Order a Jamaican Jerk burger (smoked marinated chicken and spicy sauce) or the signature pizza (tomatoes, flor di latte, Tuscan sausage and ‘nduja, the Calabrese pork sausage) whilst you pick something to spin among the various gems in the collection. At night, these 33” and 45” are given a new lease on life, used by DJs who transform the small restaurant into a trendy dance bar.

Melloo
Via Luigi Gordigiani 4r
50127 Firenze

Tel : +39 333 758 1154

https://www.melloo.it

Menu: around 8 EUR

content.title: Art and food at Manifattura Tabacchi

introduction.small: Spread over 110,000 sqm in a decommissioned tobacco factory, this new and trendy address revives the contemporary cultural offer and nightlife in Florence.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Art and food at Manifattura Tabacchi

paragraphs.text:
Between fashion, art and design, the Manifattura Tabacchi cultural centre took hold of a former 1930 tobacco factory, decommissioned in 2001. Away from the historical heart of town, the place rapidly grew into a key spot for locals. The program is filled to the brim with all kinds of exhibitions, yoga classes, trainings with the centre's craftsmen, concerts, conferences and master classes with local artists, sometimes even of national and international stature.

All 16 buildings of the Manifattura Tabacchi can be visited, as they are divided into coworking spaces, art schools, workshops and art galleries. At night, the outdoor courtyard lights up and takes over with multiple shows. It is also the occasion for some bistro-type cuisine at Bulli&Balene: an extension of the must-try restaurant located on Piazza della Passera, it offers delicious dishes like fish croquettes in aioli or corn risotto with parsley. On the bar side of things, fans of local beers will head to Birrificio Valdarno Superiore, a Tuscan microbrewery that bets on natural products and traditional techniques. As for cocktail lovers, they will make their way to Soul Kitchen and its homemade spirits and drinks. A surprising and explosive gathering of art and food!

Manifattura Tabacchi
Via delle Cascine 33/35
50144 Firenze

https://www.manifatturatabacchi.com/en/

content.title: San Lorenzo Market, awaken the senses

introduction.small: For a combination of shopping session and tastings of typical dishes, in a historical building.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: San Lorenzo Market, awaken the senses

paragraphs.text:
The San Lorenzo Market in Florence is located in the heart of the city, facing the basilica of the same name. Set up in a 19th-century building bustling with life, this trendy place develops a two-step concept: on the ground floor, you will mainly find clothes (new and thrift), as well as leather goods (handbags, belts, jackets…) and other traditional items. If you happen to be interested in bringing back a Florentine souvenir, it is recommended to bargain, according to local customs.

Under the majestic roof of the first floor, a food hall awaits your visit. You will have to choose (or not, depending on your hunger level!) among the twenty-something shops that encompass Italian cuisine in all its variety. Wine, cold cuts, truffle-based specialities and mozzarella, not mentioning pastries to be enjoyed on the spot or to go (some vacuum-packed goods may even be brought back!). A sample group like no other!

San Lorenzo Market
Piazza del Mercato Centrale

https://www.mercatocentrale.com/florence/

content.title: AdAstra, a Tuscan gem

introduction.small: In the bohemian district of Oltrano hides the exquisite AdAstra Hotel, on the first floor of a large 18th-century stately villa.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: AdAstra, a Tuscan gem

paragraphs.text:
Designed by the team behind the B&B Sopr'Arno Suites, AdAstra Hotel Particulier resides in the Giardino Torrigiani, one of the most beautiful private parks in Europe. At a ten-minute walk from Arno, you will arrive by way of the gate of Via del Campuccio. When you reach the villa that houses the AdAstra and as the heart of the garden unfolds the silhouette of a magnificent neo-Gothic tower, you already know that you will feel like a king here.
Owned by a famous Florentine family, the AdAstra occupies the entire first floor of the villa, whose main room and the common lounge are surrounded by a 270-m2 terrace overlooking the Giardino. If you can read Italian and have not brought anything to read, have no fear; the shelves are overflowing with books. As for the rooms - whether they look out onto the picturesque Via del Campuccio or massifs of the park - each unveils a unique charm, reinforced with traditional furniture, elements from distant travels or made by local craftsmen, all with a hint of Anglo-American pop. As promised, AdAstra is a real gem!

AdAstra Hotel

50125 Firenze

https://www.adastraflorence.it/

Rooms: from 179 EUR

content.title: Konnubio, the chic landmark of Florence

introduction.small: Hidden on a small quiet street, just a few metres from the San Lorenz Basilica, Konnubio offers the best of Tuscany.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Konnubio, the chic landmark of Florence

paragraphs.text:
In the very city centre of Florence, and more importantly, far from the touristy bustle that drives the “Lys City”, this small restaurant, where dim light illuminates a room with chic and rustic decoration, is a must-try. In the morning, Konnubio's breakfast mixes a classic buffet of local products and typical Italian pastries. Midday, you will enjoy a menu whose simplicity does not detract from the special attention that chef Beatrice Segoni brings to the preparation of her dishes. For dinner, the menu is enlarged to take you to the heart of the Italian boot. Dare to try, for example, the veal cheeks served with lemony potato mash and fried spinach. As for the wine, take recommendations from Simone Loguercio, their wine specialist, elected the best sommelier in Tuscany in 2018. Becoming more and more popular each day, the establishment is often full in the evenings, and reservations are therefore in order. Otherwise, you will wait while sipping on a glass of prosecco – with moderation – to the sound of jazz music. If not, you can still join Konnubio's “cocktail bar” party, another way to discover the country!

Konnubio

www.konnubio.com

Menu: from 40 EUR

content.title: Classical Italian at Montebello Splendid

introduction.small: Just a stone's throw from Florence's main tourist attractions, the Montebello Splendid offers you an Italian-style setting for a Tuscan holiday.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Classical Italian at Montebello Splendid

paragraphs.text:
A 19th-century mansion of classic beauty, the Montebello Splendid offers 60 elegant rooms, with high ceilings and adorned walls. Renaissance artwork and sumptuous draperies enhance the luxury of each room, not to mention the marble bathrooms and walk-in showers.

From your balcony, you have an unobstructed view of the gardens. In the early morning, head out to the veranda to enjoy your freshly prepared breakfast: perfumed brioche, scrambled eggs, tarts and, of course, the timeless tomato mozzarella salad. By foot, you are only a few minutes away from the Ponte Vecchio and the Uffizi Gallery. At the end of the day, choose to dine at the hotel restaurant, Capriccio, where the chef will suggest typical dishes from the region, before enjoying a last glass of Tuscan wine at Il Portico bar and settling into the park to enjoy the last rays of sun.

content.title: A charming stay at the Four Seasons

introduction.small: Nestled into a magnificent park, the Four Seasons is a true sanctuary of luxury in the heart of Florence.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A charming stay at the Four Seasons

paragraphs.text:
Next to the Giardino della Gherardesca botanical gardens, the Four Seasons welcomes you to a place that is both seductive and soothing, a place to spend a few days of pure relaxation. You will have a wide choice of luxury rooms and suites with Renaissance decor, each just as spacious and bright as the next. Divided into two distinct buildings - the Palazzo della Gherardesca from the 15th century and the Villa, an old convent from the 16th century - the hotel has a park of over 4.5 hectares in which you can enjoy a pleasant walk.

In the immense spa, you can choose from the various options available: beauty treatments, Turkish baths, exercise rooms, a swimming pool, or a whirlpool bath. Head to the Il Palagio starred restaurant to taste the best Tuscan dishes cooked with local products. For a cultural outing, you will be spoilt for choice, Four Seasons is a few minutes walk from the cathedral, art galleries and the Florence Academy of Art.

content.title: The taste of Tuscany at Il Conventino a Marignolle

introduction.small: From the heights of its panoramic terrace, rediscover all the charm and flavours of Tuscany in the Il Conventino a Marignolle restaurant.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The taste of Tuscany at Il Conventino a Marignolle

paragraphs.text:
Not far from the historical centre of Florence, in the 14th-century Renaissance-style Tolomei Villa, Il Conventino a Marignolle and its gastronomic cuisine will definitely entice you. Chef Jimi Baldazzi will prepare a succession of elegant and creative dishes with accents of Italy and a lovely touch of fantasy. Taste the vegetal minestrone or the smoked lamb chops served with tomato jelly, diced beetroot and garlic cream, and finish on a sweet note with a gianduja pie (the Piedmont chocolate spread) or the hazelnut and custard crumble pie. Sit at one of Florence's most beautiful terraces and enjoy your feast looking out over the hills of Marignolle and Bellosguardo. You can lose yourself in the extensive wine list and can even taste the Tolomei, a chianti produced directly at the vineyard of the establishment.

content.title: Museo Casa di Dante, the origins of Italian language

introduction.small: In the spring of 1265, famous writer, poet and politician Dante was born in Florence. He wrote one of the greatest masterpieces of literature: The Divine Comedy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museo Casa di Dante, the origins of Italian language

paragraphs.text:
A few steps from Piazza dei Donati, Dante Alighieri's house evokes a medieval Florence then tormented by the military and cultural conflict between the Guelphs and Ghibellines. Run down over time, the original building was rebuilt in 1911 by architect Giuseppe Castellucci, and then transformed into a museum dedicated to the life and work of Dante. On the occasion of the seventh centenary of his birth, the Santa Via Margherita complex was donated to the Unione Fiorentina by the city of Florence.

On the first floor of the house, the city of the red lily reveals its history and Dante in his youth. On the upper floor, the painful period of exile of the poet is illustrated and documented, while the last floor invites visitors to discover reproductions of famous works by Giotto, Signorelli and Michelangelo, which highlight the iconography and reputation of Dante through the centuries.

Museo Casa di Dante

50122 Firenze

https://www.museocasadidante.it/en/

content.title: Exclusive trekking and wine tour experience in Chianti

introduction.small: Discover the treasures of Tuscany beyond its Renaissance museums during a full-day hiking tour of the world-famous Chianti wine region and its magnificent wineries.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Exclusive trekking and wine tour experience in Chianti

paragraphs.text:
Tuscany's undulating hills and bucolic olive groves and vineyards landscapes inspire wanderlust the world-over. The plethora of UNESCO World Heritage Sites, its invaluable cultural patrimony, its exceptional cuisine and celebrated wines make of this central Italian region, a sought-after destination for history lovers and gourmands alike.

Its capital, Florence, is home to some of the world's most admired pieces of art and architecture, such as Michelangelo's David, the Santa-Maria del Fiore cathedral, the Uffizi Gallery, and the picturesque Ponte Vecchio. The neighbouring medieval towns of Siena or San Gimignano, and Pisa's famous leaning tower are just some of the mandatory picture-perfect stops in the region.

After a few days of museums and Renaissance masterpieces, reconnect with nature: immerse yourself in Tuscany's viticulture legacy, the world-renowned Chianti wine region. Put on your hiking shoes for an original wine tour of historical wineries, indulge in a traditional lunch paired with superb local wines, and get ready to learn the secrets of the Sangiovese grapes, the story behind the "Gallo Nero" (black rooster), and more about this classic Italian wine and its namesake village, Chianti. A memorable getaway awaits you under the Tuscan sun…

content.title: Trattoria La Casalinga, « mangiare molto et pagare poco »

introduction.small: Authentic and delicious food-and plenty of it-is to be had at the 'good housewife', as long as you do not mind waiting awhile for a table.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Trattoria La Casalinga, « mangiare molto et pagare poco »

paragraphs.text:
In the window, a white linen curtain embroidered by hand-and starched, of course-displays the name: La Casalinga. It is clear from first glance that this trattoria serves home cooking, simple, fresh, and accessible to all. The atmosphere is very friendly because everyone has a glass of chianti while waiting.

The eclectic clientele (writers, lawyers, artists, and students) are served an artichoke salad, marinated herring filets, meatloaf, spelt minestrone, sage ravioli, cannelloni, guinea fowl roast, beef carpaccio with arugula and parmesan cheese, pig feet… The Ferruccio family is from the Tuscan countryside, where people know how to put together a really big meal. They want regulars and tourists alike to leave happy and thoroughly sated.

content.title: Continentale: aperitifs on the roof overlooking the Arno

introduction.small: A very elegant ‘haute couture' address and one of the first boutique hotels in Florence. Its minimalist decor attracts fashion professionals and fans during the Pitti Immagine trade salon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Continentale: aperitifs on the roof overlooking the Arno

paragraphs.text:
This little gem, one of the six establishments in the Lungarno Collection of the Salvatore Ferragamo Group, sings fashion from every angle. Witness in the early 1950s to the first ready-to-wear fashion show, which was held at the Palazzo Pitti, the Continentale's rooms, corridors, lounge, and bar are filled with black and white fashion photographs.

The Florentine interior designer Michele Bönan was inspired by the all-white Sala Bianca of the Palazzo Pitti, where Italian designers like Irene Galitzine, Carosi, and, of course, Salvatore Ferragamo held their runway shows. The decor is refined and immaculate, with beautiful, handcrafted and custom-made leather furniture. In addition, at any time of day or night, you can take a glass al fresco in La Terrazza bar on the top floor of the medieval Consorti tower.

content.title: Gallery Art Hotel: atypical and connected to contemporary art

introduction.small: Art happenings and temporary exhibitions are held in this hotel frequented by fans of design and modernism, who are like fish in water here—as it is so close to the Arno…

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gallery Art Hotel: atypical and connected to contemporary art

paragraphs.text:
A boutique hotel situated by the Ponte Vecchio, this other elegant jewel of the Ferragamo family is in perpetual motion. One day, it hosts an exhibition of photographs by David LaChapelle, another, those of Steven Klein or Lise Sarfati, followed by a retrospective of Magnum cult photographer Elliott Erwitt. In the cradle of the Renaissance, the Gallery Art Hotel, precursor of Florence's hotel renewal, still stands out like a UFO.

The artist and designer Simone D'Auria books the art happenings throughout the year. He hung windmills on the facade, accompanied by the bright red letters WOW to raise awareness regarding the use of renewable sources of energy. From inside its high-design rooms of Asian-inspired décor, it is impossible to conceive that the throngs of tourists strolling on the Ponte Vecchio or queued at the entrance of the Uffizi Gallery are just a few steps away. With a pool in the basement, a lounge on the roof, and breakfasts fit for a king-could life really be this good?

content.title: Ditta Artigianale: the best coffee and more

introduction.small: The talented barista Francesco Sanapo, three-time winner of the best coffee in Italy prize, has opened a second spot, signed by the great urbanist Giovanni Michelucci.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ditta Artigianale: the best coffee and more

paragraphs.text:
It is difficult to impress Italians with coffee-they have it in their genes. But this barista has met the challenge brilliantly. Now he has opened a second address in the magnificent building of the pope of modernism, architect Giovanni Michelucci, author of the Florence train station and the 'Church of the Freeway of the Sun'. He has created a place of simple beauty that is well suited to the rare coffees of Francesco Sanapo.

A native of Salento and Florentine by adoption, Francesco perfected the art of espresso behind the counter of the family bistro in Lecce. Today, the maestro offers rare vintages like Esmeralda Gesha, a Panamanian coffee grown at an altitude of 2,000 metres, or nectar from Guatemala, produced in small quantities. The coffee is roasted on site, in specially crafted machines. Dishes offered include an excellent ham and cheese sandwich, pane carasau turnovers (Sardinian bread), and other 'brasserie' classics at unbeatable prices. The market-based à la carte menu includes delicious gourmet mini-portions.

Ditta Artigianale

content.title: Fishing Lab, freshly caught fish

introduction.small: Located inside the Palazzo dell'Arte dei Giudici e Notai (Palace of the Art of Judges and Notaries) is a restaurant-museum filled with secular paintings from the Middle Ages.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fishing Lab, freshly caught fish

paragraphs.text:
An architectural treasure of the Trecento (14th century) and a symbol of the pre-Renaissance (the Renascimento), the Palazzo dell'Arte dei Giudici e Notai sits upon archaeological remains from the Roman era and the Middle Ages. In 2005, researchers found a series of portraits of the poets Dante, Petrarch, and Boccaccio, commissioned for the Palazzo Vecchio.

In this historic place, the maritime atmosphere almost gives you the impression of sailing the ocean. Chi ama il mare ama Fishing Lab they say, who loves the sea loves Fishing Lab. Almost a proverb, the sentence rings like a slogan for this restaurant where fish is king. Raw or cooked, but always caught on the day, it is always perfectly prepared. From rockfish nuggets to seafood arancini, salted cod cooked in rosemary and a whole seabass, you will find seafood in every shape of form. A pure delight for all food lovers.

content.title: Basilica di Santo Spirito: where business joins pleasure

introduction.small: Don't be fooled by the surprising simplicity of its facade: this is a great spot to soak up the festive spirit of this very popular area, especially at night.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Basilica di Santo Spirito: where business joins pleasure

paragraphs.text:
Built on the beautifully wooded eponymous square, the Basilica of the Holy Spirit was designed by the architect Filippo Brunelleschi, the theorist of mathematical perspective, who never got a chance to finish it. After his death in 1446, ten years after the start of work, his disciple and biographer Antonio Manetti took over-and it was he who decided to leave the facade bare.

The perfect unity of the interior is based on the Latin cross, with three naves; the altar and canopy were executed in the 17th century by the goldsmith Giovanni Battista Caccini in polychrome marbles, bronze, and stone. Take a tour of Santo Spirito's 36 chapels, which hold many masterworks, including The Virgin and Child by Filippino Lippi. The sacristy contains an early work by Michelangelo, a touching Christ carved in wood. Upon leaving, linger in one of the cafés on the piazza or have a delicious, all-natural gelato at the Gelateria della Passera.

Basilica di Santo Spirito

50125 Firenze

content.title: Cibrèo: helmed by a culinary maestro

introduction.small: It is difficult to find more typical Florentine fare than at this chef's table near Sant'Ambrogio market, a favourite for its traditional dishes, many of which date back to the Renaissance.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cibrèo: helmed by a culinary maestro

paragraphs.text:
Do not grimace upon hearing that the 16th-century dish cibrèo is made from poultry offal (chicken liver, heart, testicles, strawberry, and cockscomb) dipped in a spicy sauce with garlic and sage. In war against modern cuisine, chef Fabio Picchi awakens stomachs of the new millennium, accustomed to more lightness, with bread soups and paisano cabbage dishes, whole rabbit stuffed with onion leaves or potato cakes – rest assured, however, that every mouthful is as light as air...

From the kitchen open onto the dining room, the chef's typical Italian banter fills the air, calling out to customers with a joke or a song. The ambiance is more than welcoming and harks back to the inns of yesteryear. If you do not give in to the lamb brains in parchment, do not miss the delicious ricotta pie!

introduction.small: Using Murano glass and Bohemian crystal, designer Ornella Aprosio designs ​​wonderful jewellery in the shape of flowers, insects, and fruit.

paragraphs.text:
Near the San Lorenzo basilica, craftsperson and artist Ornella Aprosio runs an elegant boutique decorated like a delicate art deco boudoir where she makes her unique handcrafted jewellery. Following an old Venetian tradition that dates back to the 16th century, she crochets and knits together colourful glass beads and Bohemian crystals to make the necklaces, bracelets, rings, and earrings Italian families used to pass down as talismans.

To do this precious, slow, and minute work, Aprosio has trained young women who deftly produce impressive cherry pendants, butterfly brooches, and evening bags: certain celebrities are fans of the evening bags, especially, but she has promised not to reveal their names. Come and fall under the spell of this poetic universe.

content.title: Academy Gallery: biblical heroes, sketches, and violins...

introduction.small: In the small, quiet area of San Marco is Michelangelo's 'David', wonderful plaster studies, and a gallery dedicated to musical instruments.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Academy Gallery: biblical heroes, sketches, and violins...

paragraphs.text:
Even if you are not an art buff, you should visit the Galleria dell'Accademia, if only to rave over Michelangelo's statue of David. Carved from a block of Carrara marble, the 5.5 tonne Colossus, measuring 5.17 metres in height, and executed between 1501 and 1504, was commissioned to be a symbol of the nascent Florentine Republic.

Since 1873, Michelangelo's masterpiece has presided over the Galleria dei Prigioni, which includes a bronze bust by his pupil Daniele da Volterra and Michelangelo's Captives, the four statues he carved for the tomb of Pope Julius II in Rome, which was never completed. To the left of this gallery are sublime 19th-century plaster casts attributed to sculptor Lorenzo Bartolini. Another curiosity, which is not as frequented, is a tiny part of the museum devoted to musical instruments, with violins by Antonio Stradivari.

Illustrious families inhabited it before it became the Piccioli pension in the 19th century. Some suites have private steam rooms or Jacuzzis. The most spectacular is the panoramic suite. Fortunately, its 360-degree view of the dome of Santa Maria del Fiore and the hills of Fiesole and Settignano can also be enjoyed from the terrace adjacent to the bar. From breakfast onward, music lovers flock to the Sound Immersion Salotto for its superb sound system to listen, as if they were at the opera, to the tenor Ugo Tarquini.

content.title: Basilica of San Lorenzo: a great inner beauty

introduction.small: To escape the hubbub of the market in front of it, take refuge in the silence of this basilica's sublime nave and sacristy, with its friezes of carved cherubs.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Basilica of San Lorenzo: a great inner beauty

paragraphs.text:
At the request of the Medici clan, Brunelleschi erected this basilica in 1425, taking care, as usual, to emphasise balance and harmony. At the architect's death, Michelangelo designed the facade, but it was deemed too expensive by its sponsor, Pope Leo X. The bas-reliefs recounting the life of Christ, St. John the Baptist, and the Resurrection, the two chairs carved in bronze, and the sacristy decorated with friezes of carved cherubs were the last works of the great sculptor Donatello, who lies next to Cosimo de Medici in the crypt of the adjoining cloister.

The Marriage of the Virgin by Rosso Fiorentino, The Martyrdom of St. Lawrence by Bronzino, the painted sarcophagus by Leonardo da Vinci... San Lorenzo hides many wonders and secrets: chased by the Medici, Michelangelo found refuge in the sacristy. In 1975, the charcoal sketches of the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel were found here.

Basilica di San Lorenzo
Piazza di San Lorenzo 9
50123 Firenze

content.title: Gucci Garden: voyage to the heart of luxury and art

introduction.small: A symbol of the glamorous 1960s, the Florentine brand, famous worldwide, understatedly displays its creations, along with books and contemporary art.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gucci Garden: voyage to the heart of luxury and art

paragraphs.text:
In an exquisite Renaissance palace, the famous Gucci brand exhibits the unostentatious travel articles and iconic bags created by its founder, the Florentine Guccio Gucci. Son of a leather-goods craftsman, Guccio left for Paris and London, where he worked as a lift operator in palace hotels. The luxury luggage of the clients captured his imagination. Back in Florence, he created his first pieces on the theme of horse riding. Then, just after the war, his Bamboo bag became a cult item…

At his death in 1953, his four sons took over the company and launched the famous green-red-green Gucci crest and the double G logo. Famous for its style, the brand, led today by Alessandro Michele and belonging to the Kering group, opened its museum, café, and bookstore. On the ground floor, you can peruse rare art and fashion books, while the top floor is devoted to the works of some of the most important contemporary artists of our day.

Gucci Garden

50122 Firenze

content.title: Pop over to Fiesole to see its Roman amphitheatre

introduction.small: To get some fresh air and altitude in summer, take a nine-kilometre bus drive from Florence to this picturesque and bucolic town.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pop over to Fiesole to see its Roman amphitheatre

paragraphs.text:
To reach Fiesole, perched 300 m above sea level on a hillside northeast of Florence, just hop on bus number 7 (Piazza San Marco) and press your nose against the window to admire the passing scenery of cypress and olive trees, small churches, and steep roads. On its main square, Fiesole has many cafés and a flea market much frequented by Florentines. Far from the throngs of tourists, it has long been a haven for dreamers, including Marcel Proust and André Gide.

While some visitors are content just to take in its panoramic views after a nice walk to the convent of San Francesco, others continue on to its archaeological site, occupied by the Etruscans and the Romans, who built a huge amphitheatre. The truly curious carry on to Villa Medici, the first Renaissance home with its own garden.

content.title: On the other side of the Arno, the impressive Pitti Palace

introduction.small: Cross the Ponte Vecchio and stroll on the left bank of the Arno, the Oltrarno, with an ice cream. After Palazzo Pitti, take a break in the Boboli Gardens...

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: On the other side of the Arno, the impressive Pitti Palace

paragraphs.text:
Fashionistas all head for Pitti Immagine, the ready-to-wear trade show. But this colossus offers much more than that... Designed by Brunelleschi in the 15th century for the banker Pitti, it fell into the hands of Cosimo I, who made it the residence of the Medici dynasty. His wife, Eleanor of Toledo, enhanced the Boboli Gardens, designed by Niccolò Tribolo, who decorated and designed royal celebrations. It is a good place for a break after visiting the Pitti's six museums.

The Palatine Gallery, decorated with frescoes and trompe l'oeil stucco, exhibits works by Titian and Fra Filippo Lippi as well as masterpieces by Raphael, including The Madonna of Impannata. The silver, porcelain, and costume museums are full of treasures. After daydreaming in the royal apartments, end your visit at the Gallery of Modern Art, an irresistible haven of 18th-century decorative arts.

content.title: Palazzo Medici Riccardi: a very quiet baroque hymn to Italy

introduction.small: At the beginning of the Via Cavour, this peaceful palace has many masterworks, including the Chapel of the Magi and the ceiling of the hall of mirrors.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Palazzo Medici Riccardi: a very quiet baroque hymn to Italy

paragraphs.text:
Cosimo de Medici (called Cosimo the Elder) was looking to hide his fortune. He amassed it by skilfully investing in wool and international trade. It then grew even bigger when the Black Death brought forward the decline of the most powerful families in the city. In 1444, he therefore asked the architect Michelozzo di Bartolomeo Michelozzi to erect a building of modesty and religious austerity. The goldsmith and engraver at the Florence mint made the future home of the Medici an example of a Florentine palace with softly lit facades, a huge cornice, and a courtyard surrounded by a portico with ancient columns. After several changes of ownership, the palace reverted to the city of Florence in 1874, which still runs it today.

Do not miss the treasure buried in the chapel: the flamboyantly colourful The Procession of the Magi by Benozzo Gozzoli, a large and colourful work that covers three walls in the room. Also noteworthy, admire the ceiling fresco running the entire length of the hall of mirrors, The Apotheosis of the Medici, by Luca Giordano, a baroque painter of the Neapolitan school.

Palazzo Medici Riccardi

content.title: Palazzo Vecchio: a much prettier name than ‘Old Palace'

introduction.small: This veritable open-air museum is a palace whose 94-metre-tall tower has stood above the Piazza della Signoria for seven centuries. It was turned into the city hall in 1871.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Palazzo Vecchio: a much prettier name than ‘Old Palace'

paragraphs.text:
Formerly named Palazzo della Signoria, it was renamed the 'Old Palace' when the Medici left it for the Pitti Palace. Its tower, built by architect Arnolfo di Cambio, overlooks the Fountain of Neptune by Florentine sculptor Bartolomeo Ammannati, which was the first artwork displaying nudity in a public place. In its courtyard, transformed into a portico by Michelozzo, stands another fountain with a copy of a bronze statue by Verrocchio.

On the first floor, in the Salone dei Cinquecento, the frescoes and paintings by Vasari will bring tears to your eyes. Among the two rows of 16th-century statues is Michelangelo's The Genius of Victory. There is also the secret and allegorical office of Francesco I de 'Medici. On the second floor, you will find the apartments of Cosimo I, decorated in mythological frescoes, and those of Eleonora of Toledo, home to a tiny chapel painted by Bronzino. It is all simply astonishing!

content.title: Mulino di Firenze: recapture the spirit of Malaparte's Tuscany

introduction.small: Just 20 minutes outside of the city, amidst the beautiful hills of Chianti, this old mill offers another form of Tuscan bliss.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mulino di Firenze: recapture the spirit of Malaparte's Tuscany

paragraphs.text:
Nestled between the Val de Pisa and the Arno Valley, this former mill built in 1330 retained its heavy beams, solid oak reservoirs, conducts to carry the river water, and most especially the agricultural soul of Tuscans. Enter the building and immediately travel back in time, in a rural country that saw the birth of Renaissance architecture. Mulino de Firenze invites all guests to roam the countryside, source of endless gustatory pleasures.

Only five kilometres separate Florence from this former mill, but it feels miles away from the city bustle. Housed in the ancient wheat barns, rooms and suites offer all modern comfort, topped with wrought-iron beds and lighting with bronze cherubs. Time stands still as you appreciate the delight of cool marble floors, unobstructed views of the surroundings and, last but not least, the restaurant's exceptional cuisine.

content.title: Quinoa: the first gluten-free restaurant in Florence

introduction.small: Full of surprises, Quinoa features great burgers and salads. Allergic to gluten or not, this is a treat for everybody.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Quinoa: the first gluten-free restaurant in Florence

paragraphs.text:
Housed in the monumental cloisters of the church of Santa Maria di Novella, Florence's first gluten-free restaurant is in a dream location for a lunchtime break. Under the beautiful arches of the 13th-century building, the chef and his team serve healthy food that is fresh, organic and tasty.

The organic produce comes from small Tuscan producers who have vowed to emphasize organic and sustainable agriculture, and the centrepiece is quinoa, which they prepare creatively in a thousand and one ways. Dubbed the 'rice of the Incas', it contains 70% carbohydrates, 15% protein, very little fat, lots of minerals and, especially, no gluten. The space is charming, with big flowerpots and tables set up in the courtyard of the cloister. In Florence, you will be hard-pressed to find another place like it!

content.title: Palazzo del Marchese di Camugliano, a 16th-century palace

introduction.small: This extraordinary Renaissance palace is right next to the Santa Maria Novella station, making it very convenient for those day trips to Pisa and Siena by train.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Palazzo del Marchese di Camugliano, a 16th-century palace

paragraphs.text:
Crossing the courtyard that leads to the reception, imagine yourself being expected by the Marquis Lorenzo Niccolini, marchese di Camugliano himself, the master who transformed his family residence into a hotel. A kind of living museum of the Florentine Renaissance, the palace has been renovated to perfection. The bathrooms are all in marble and the coffered ceilings, of an impressive height (five metres), still have their original frescoes, beautifully restored.

No rooms or apartments are alike. Sumptuous furnishings, antique canopy beds, stucco, marble fireplaces, Murano chandeliers, luxurious drapes - it is almost like sleeping in an antique shop, such as those on the Via dei Fossi, which is located just behind the hotel. The old kitchen has been converted into a gym and, on the roof, a wonderful garden awaits you for an aperitif or a breakfast of delicious breads and homemade cakes.

content.title: The Uffizi Gallery: an anthology of Italian art

introduction.small: Extremely popular year-round, this palace, which was originally intended for administrative affairs, holds many treasures. The queues are long, so equip yourself with patience or a museum pass.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Uffizi Gallery: an anthology of Italian art

paragraphs.text:
Florentines are very proud of their museum and some even compare it to the Louvre, the National Gallery in London, and the Prado in Madrid... Banker and head of state during the Italian Renaissance, Cosimo I, duke of Tuscany, known as Cosimo the Elder, chose architect Giorgio Vasari to build the offices (uffizi in Italian) of the grand Duchy. A philanthropist at heart, de' Medici was generous to artists, as was his son, the aesthete Francesco I de' Medici, who transformed it into a museum.

With The Birth of Venus and Primavera by Botticelli, the Doni Tondo by Michelangelo, and portraits of the Medicis by Bronzino and Raphael, see the history of the Medici dynasty, discover the unfinished Adoration of the Magi by Leonardo da Vinci and The Annunciation by Simone Martini, master of the Sienese school of the 14th century. In order to take in the extraordinary richness of the collections in the Uffizi Gallery as they deserve, we recommend multiple visits!

content.title: Volume: live music in a former wood-carving workshop

introduction.small: Culture-hungry Florentines and arty expat hipsters gather at this former sculpture workshop, which is now a lively bar and bookstore—and, on Thursday nights, a concert hall.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Volume: live music in a former wood-carving workshop

paragraphs.text:
The former workshop of the wood sculptor Alfonso Bini, a tiny spot crowded with beautiful moulds, hat forms, woodworking tools, and old machines, was founded in 1887, and harkens back to a time when the neighbourhood was inhabited by artisans. Added to the mix is a happy mishmash of 1950s objects, including a jukebox and mismatched Formica kitchen chairs.

In a very friendly atmosphere, the regulars, always people of strong character, come to eat hazelnut cocoa spread crepes or artisanal ice cream from Gelateria Carabè while flipping through books and magazines that are for sale or just there to look at. On Thursday evening it becomes a live-music venue. During the rest of the week, Volume stays open until the end of the night, or, more precisely, until the last classic cocktails and glasses of beer, Italian and imported, have been served…

A peaceful five-star hotel, Ville sull'Arno is absolutely ideal for travellers seeking wellness, exercise, and tranquillity. The 45 rooms are spacious and modern, with vintage objects that give the impression of being welcome at a friend's. The Villino Spa is a major delight, with its wooden tubs, Turkish steam room, indoor swimming pool, and a full treatment menu to get you quickly back in form. Some rooms have Jacuzzis. In the evening, try the fresh and refined cuisine at the poolside restaurant Flora e Fauno. An all-around pleasant experience.

content.title: Vivoli: the flavours of Italy in a “gelato artigianalo”

introduction.small: Just steps from the Santa Croce Basilica and the Museo dell'Opera, Vivoli dishes out delicious ice cream until midnight.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vivoli: the flavours of Italy in a “gelato artigianalo”

paragraphs.text:
Admire the frescoes of Giotto, look in at the nave of the basilica and the tombs of Michelangelo, Galileo, and Machiavelli, and the cenotaph of Dante. Join the horde of tourists in the cloister, now the Museo dell'Opera, and stand transfixed before the bronze of Saint Louis of Toulouse by Donatello. Linger in the Pazzi chapel, admiring its dome decorated with glazed ceramics by Luca della Robbia. Then head straight to Vivoli for a pear-caramel or chocolate-orange ice cream.

A small dairy converted into an ice-cream parlour in 1932, Serafino Vivoli has built its reputation on its unparalleled knack for whipping cream. The Florentines consider it the best in the city for its homemade ice cream crafted from seasonal ingredients and served in cardboard pots. Make the best of this gourmet break and explore this authentic neighbourhood left unscathed.

content.title: Three in one: the Duomo, baptistery, and campanile

introduction.small: Visit the Old Town in early morning when the sun illuminates Giotto's bell tower, the roof of the baptistery, and the red dome of the cathedral.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Three in one: the Duomo, baptistery, and campanile

paragraphs.text:
A jewel of Gothic architecture, the bell tower of the cathedral, designed by Giotto and completed by Francesco Talenti, can be visited from 8:15 a.m. It is decorated with reliefs and statues of the great masters of the Renaissance, and, after climbing up 414 steps, it offers a breath-taking view of the city.

In the very simple nave of the Cathedral of Santa Maria del Fiore (the real name of the 'Duomo'), linger in front of Dante Explaining the Divine Comedy by Domenico di Michelino, Giorgio Vasari's fresco of the Last Judgement which decorates Filippo Brunelleschi's dome, and the gigantic clock by Paolo Uccello before exploring the Museo dell'Opera del Duomo, inaugurated in October 2015. A modern gem that houses some 750 works, it includes the Florentine Pietà, Michelangelo's last sculpture. If you still have time, do not miss the baptistery of San Giovanni, made of polychromatic marble and tiles.

content.title: Madova: a style that fits you like a glove

introduction.small: This unassuming little shop does not look like it hides great treasures and a long history, but the Donnini family has been making gloves since 1919.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Madova: a style that fits you like a glove

paragraphs.text:
Having spent hours scrutinising the fabulous windows of the jewellers shops on the Ponte Vecchio, the oldest bridge in Florence and the only one not bombed during the Second World War, leave the Uffizi behind and head to the main street. There, you will come face to face with the shop of the Donnini family, glove makers from father to son since 1919.

Trained in the art of tanning and leather processing, which Florence has been famous for since the Middle Ages, they are the only ones to make and sell leather gloves in the traditional way. The shop looks right out of the1950s - it opened in 1954 - and experienced vendors measure and talc your hand before each fitting. This is the perfect place to find unique models, such as driving gloves in leather and cotton, in beautiful colours and at affordable prices.

While nail bars are popping up in every city of the world, Florence only opened its first nail bar in spring 2015! This is a first for the always prim and elegant Florentines, and an extraordinary boon for tourists who walk all day and want to take a break.

Cosily decorated in powder pink, the nail bar offers spa treatments for the feet and manicures for the hands. Indulge yourself while sipping a spritz, a coffee, or bitters while chiacchiere (chatting) with the person sitting next to you. After a relaxing 90-minute footbath, massage, and nail polish, tackle the Ognissanti church, just steps away on the Piazza Ognissanti. In the centre of the nave is the famous St. Augustine in His Study by Botticelli and Saint Jerome in His Study by Ghirlandaio.

In a room adorned with blue and grey Fornasetti wallpaper, Gurdulù borrowed its name from a character in Italo Calvino's novel The Non-Existent Knight. A major player among Florence's restaurants due to the culinary creativity of its young chef Gabriele Andreoni, it highlights raw materials, unique combinations of flavours and textures, refined plates and seasonal recipes. Gurdulù is a refuge of Florentine bistronomy.

In an intimate dining room that sits 30, the atmosphere is pared down, almost feng shui. Non-stop gastronomical experiences are to be expected: zucchini, tonka beans, red shrimp, burrata and saffron, black tea spaghetti, urchins, cherries and salmon caviar, duck with kumquats, capers and wasabi… and a "white on white" finish of white peach, white grapefruit and ginger and white chocolate! Lit by 1940s light fixtures, equipped with large and very comfortable mahogany beds, and decorated with large mirrors, the unique and welcoming establishment remains affordable for all budgets. In E.M. Forster's famous novel A Room with a View, the heroine Lucy Honeychurch was annoyed not to have a room with a river view. To avoid the same fate, remember to book the suite that overlooks the Arno.

Sunday is a 'lunch de la nonna' (grandmother) of roast chicken. Other dishes include a sole with capers, mashed potatoes and artichokes, a breaded escalope with saffron rice and string beans or a Tuscan beef lasagne in Chianina sauce, all served with olive oil from San Vincenzo, where Fulvio had his restaurant Gambero Rosso, once the most famous restaurant in the world.

content.title: Giulia Materia: the beautiful art of recycling paper

introduction.small: This young designer revives one of the oldest Florentine crafts, stationery, using the techniques of old and recycled paper, to create beautiful books and objects.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Giulia Materia: the beautiful art of recycling paper

paragraphs.text:
In her workshop-boutique 20 m from Palazzo Pitti, the young Giulia became famous for her technique of bookbinding and printing on paper. Inspired by the tradition of Florentine stationery, Giulia lets her imagination run wild, reproducing in paper the lozenges and gilding seen everywhere in Florence. She invents playful patterns, customises vintage wallpapers and tapestries from Germany or scavenged in Italy, which she reworks with the tip of her brush.

Her workspace is a work of art in itself: a countertop recuperated from a Rimini hotel, lamps and armchairs from the 1960s… With recycled paper she creates objects that children and grownups adore. Among the bric-a-brac, you can unearth travel diaries, old and new postcards, and beribboned computer and iPad pouches. Brimming with creativity, she also launched a handmade clothing line (blouses, long and short skirts, sweatshirts…) easy to recognise with its simple, colourful and meticulous style.

content.title: Hotel Pendini: where time stands still

Wallpaper brightens the walls of the 42 huge rooms-some are triples, and the family suites can accommodate five people. The varnished vintage furniture contrasts nicely with the Pendini's classic decor. Owned since its creation in 1879 by successive families, its long, elegant corridors, cosy lounges, and refined breakfast room feel just like home.

Windows open on one side to a network of small streets and on the other to Piazza della Repubblica. The hotel is housed on the top floor of a palace from the Risanamento period, a time of ambitious, large-scale urban redevelopment following unification. content.title: The Ménagère: the ‘grande bellezza' of Italian cuisine

introduction.small: You will want to spend hours in this wonderful spot, which serves home cooking just like mamma's, with a touch of ultra-modernity to awaken the taste buds. Sublime!

The first housewares shop in Florence, open since 1896, houses under its giant glass roof a 1,500-sqm concept restaurant on two floors, designed by architects Luca and Marco Baldini of the Q-Bic studio. Exposed metal structures, rough walls, period floor tiles-the industrial decor is softened by a few contemporary design elements and the lovely wooden tables and chairs.

This hybrid location brings everything together: locals come and eat something on the fly, or have a drink with friends, gather and party until midnight, or even shop! You can buy the Karman light fixtures that illuminate the white ceramic dishes in which the food is served, along with perfumes, flowers, and rare plants. The food is listed as 'hot and cold', 'soft-crunchy' or 'sweet and sour'. The perfect place for lunch-at two in the morning!

content.title: Museo del Bargello: for lovers of Renaissance sculpture

introduction.small: Tuscan statues grace every floor of this impregnable fortress, one of the first national museums in Italy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museo del Bargello: for lovers of Renaissance sculpture

paragraphs.text:
Destined initially for the Podesta, the city's high officials in the late Middle Ages, this 1255 building has undergone many restorations without losing any of its medieval allure. A prison for three centuries, it served as the headquarters of the police captain, the bargello. The interior courtyard was the macabre scene of executions until the 19th century, when the building became one of the first museums in Italy.

Instead of dwelling on this chapter of its history, head straight to the bronze statue A Little Fisher, by Vincenzo Gemito, before climbing to the first floor, which is dedicated to Donatello's David, his Amore-Attis, and his masterful Marzocco, the symbol of Florence, a copy of which stands in front of the Palazzo Vecchio. As the visit is chronological, you finish in the hall of the Cinquecento, which holds many works by Michelangelo, including early pieces like the unfinished Bacchus.

content.title: Pegna: where Florentines do their grocery shopping

introduction.small: You cannot leave the city without taking some Tuscan delicacies with you. Though near the Duomo, this house, founded in 1860, is not a tourist trap. Quite the contrary!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pegna: where Florentines do their grocery shopping

paragraphs.text:
If you missed Sant'Ambrogio Market, nestled in the beautiful glass and iron hall in Piazza Lorenzo Ghiberti, go straight to this gastronomic institution founded in 1860. The vaulted ceilings of this 15th-century building once housed a paint shop, and there are still many in this neighbourhood. The Florentines shop here for local produce, as well as for the full range of specialties from elsewhere.

Huge, incredibly busy, and with over 7,000 different products on offer, this is a paradise of gluttony. There is delicious handmade pasta, fragrant white truffles, cheeses from all parts of the country, an enchanting cellar, a rigorous selection of olive oils, chocolates, and homemade biscuits, and every type of Tuscan meat. Oddly enough, a small drugstore is hidden in the back of the shop, and that can come in handy.

content.title: The St. Regis Florence: as luxurious as it gets

introduction.small: Unforgettable and exceptional, this five-star hotel, housed in a historic building designed by the great Renaissance architect Filippo Brunelleschi, deserves at least a one-night stay.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The St. Regis Florence: as luxurious as it gets

paragraphs.text:
Formerly the private palace of a Florentine aristocrat, the St. Regis Florence was turned into a hotel in the 19th century. Situated on the Arno, its creamy facade hides a grandiose decor, from the lobby to the salons, bar, suites, and rooms. If you dream of a romantic holiday, book one of the modernised rooms, which still sparkle with works of art, frescoes, sculpted beds, and crystal chandeliers.

The 200-sqm Renaissance-styled presidential suite overlooks Ponte Vecchio and comes with a private butler. Tomas Maier, the creative director of the brand Bottega Veneta, famous for its leather bags, designed the fashionable Bottega Veneta Suite. After a visit to the Clarins Spa and fitness centre, indulge yourself further at the Michelin-star chef Gentian Shehi's restaurant, the Winter Garden by Caino.

content.title: The Officina Santa Maria Novella: thank you, Dominican monks!

introduction.small: From the wonderful trompe l'oeil by Masaccio to the bewitching scent of one of the oldest pharmacies in the world, everything is a pretext to make an appointment.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Officina Santa Maria Novella: thank you, Dominican monks!

paragraphs.text:
Before discovering this den of magical perfumes and herbs, be sure to explore the Santa Maria Novella church, founded by the Dominican monks in the 13th century. Behind its polychrome marble facade, made ​​in 1470 by Alberti, works by Botticelli (The Nativity), Giotto (a crucifix painted a tempera), Masaccio (The Trinity, a first trompe-l'oeil), Domenico Ghirlandaio (extraordinary frescoes), and Filippino Lippi will leave you speechless.

The Dominican fathers, who lived in the nearby cloister (located on the Piazza della Stazione and now a museum), cultivated medicinal herbs for the pharmacy of the convent. In 1866, it was bought by the Stefani family, to whom the monks passed on their secrets. The dispensary is in the former chapel of the monks. Amidst a collection of stills, books, and ceramic pots from Montelupo, you can choose balms and violet soaps, as well as the captivating Acqua della Regina worn by Catherine de Medici and since renamed 'Acqua di Colonia'...

 

Officina Profumo Farmaceutica di Santa Maria Novella

content.title: Regency Hotel: a garden in the heart of the city

introduction.small: This is a lovely spot to call home close to the Jewish Museum and the synagogue, with a very friendly staff, and balconies overlooking the garden.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Regency Hotel: a garden in the heart of the city

paragraphs.text:
With only 32 rooms, the Regency is a real Florentine villa, built outside the historic centre and surrounded by a private, very quiet garden. The spirit of Tuscany awaits you on the terrace and balconies, which open onto this green area and its restaurant, the Relais Le Jardin. It is a wonderful holiday resort for those who want to escape the crowds, yet it is close to everything, including the largest (and most beautiful) Italian synagogue, which is only five minutes' away on foot. Sublimely restored by the Salvatore Ferragamo Group, it was built in Moorish style between 1874 and 1882. The white marble facade hides a pink and red interior painted in the Byzantine style. Upstairs, visit its small Jewish Museum, before settling in to snack on falafels and other vegetarian and kosher dishes at Ruth's, a favourite of Woody Allen's.

content.title: Salvatore Ferragamo: the cobbler who became shoemaker to the stars

introduction.small: Overlooking the Via Tornabuoni, the Palazzo Spini Feroni houses the museum and headquarters of the Salvatore Ferragamo group. A must for lovers of shoes and art.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Salvatore Ferragamo: the cobbler who became shoemaker to the stars

paragraphs.text:
The story of Salvatore Ferragamo would make a great film. At 14, the little Neapolitan lad from Bonito, apprenticed to a shoemaker in Naples, leaves for America to join his brother in a footwear company in Boston. In the early 1920s, he opens a shop in Hollywood and makes shoes for Mary Pickford, Rudolf Valentino, and Douglas Fairbanks among others...

Back in Italy, he chooses Florence to make his mark. His Cork Wedges and reinforced high heels are snapped up by Marilyn Monroe, Greta Garbo, Sophia Loren, Anna Magnani, the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, and Audrey Hepburn. All the stars come to his shop in the Palazzo Spini Feroni, which was built in 1289 and acquired by Salvatore in 1938. The museum opened in 1995, and displays around 10,000 models by the shoemaking genius, as well as contemporary works of art.

content.title: Plaza Hotel Lucchesi: an old family pension from the 1920s

introduction.small: Not far from the picture-postcard view displayed on its website, this hotel delivers a modern version of Belle Epoque comfort.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Plaza Hotel Lucchesi: an old family pension from the 1920s

paragraphs.text:
The past itself is part of the beautiful view from the stately staircase leading to the rooms. The happy times of the Roaring Twenties, when it was still possible to take a dip in the Arno, and such luxuries as central heating and running water were new to the area. Dream once more about times past and find, in each of the 82 rooms and 10 family suites overlooking the Arno, the hill of San Miniato al Monte, Piazzale Michelangelo and the red roofs of the city centre, a bit of the casualness that is still so much a part of Florence. Relax on the roof of the Plaza Hotel Lucchesi in one of the two pools or at the bar, which are open from 9:00 a.m. until midnight. Situated on the right bank of the river, near the Piazza Santa Croce, you would be hard-pressed to find a better location. The four-star service is outstanding.

content.title: Quelle Tre: a ‘not-fashion' shop run by three very chic sisters

introduction.small: Born into a family of tailors, the Scardigli sisters have been expressing their vision of feminine elegance since 1989. Discover unique items on Via Santa Spirito.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Quelle Tre: a ‘not-fashion' shop run by three very chic sisters

paragraphs.text:
They left Via Pucci to settle in the Oltrarno district, the long-time home of Florentine artisans. Leather workers, glove makers, jewellers, and stationers all had workshops here, which gradually became shops. In the best Florentine tradition, Cecilia, Luciana, and Cristiana Scardigli use only the finest materials, and everything is handmade. They do not follow fashion trends, instead choosing to create truly elegant clothing in very precious and refined fabrics.

From the extravagant to the sensible, their collections highlight the three essential pieces of the feminine wardrobe: skirt, trousers, and dresses in bold colours and cut to suit all body types and ages. Pretty accessories accompany them. If you are a fan, you can also leave with their book Quelle Tre: 25 anni di moda not ('25 years of non-fashion') published in Italian and English by Nardini editions.

Quelle Tre

50125 Firenze
